message_1: A sample contains an unknown radioactive isotope. The gamma spectrum of the sample shows three main peaks at energies of 511 keV, 662 keV, and 1173 keV. Using this information and your knowledge of gamma spectroscopy, determine the identity of the isotope and its decay mode.
message_2:
The gamma spectrum of the sample shows three main peaks at energies of 511 keV, 662 keV, and 1173 keV. These energies correspond to specific gamma-ray emissions from radioactive isotopes.

The 511 keV peak is a common energy associated with the annihilation of an electron and a positron, which is a characteristic of positron emission or β+ decay.

The 662 keV peak corresponds to the gamma-ray emission from the decay of Cs-137 (Cesium-137) to Ba-137m (Barium-137 metastable state). Cs-137 undergoes beta decay (β-) to form Ba-137m.

The 1173 keV peak corresponds to the gamma-ray emission from the decay of Co-60 (Cobalt-60) to Ni-60 (Nickel-60). Co-60 undergoes beta decay (β-) to form Ni-60.

Considering the presence of the 511 keV peak, it is likely that the sample contains a mixture of isotopes. The presence of the 662 keV and 1173 keV peaks suggests that the sample contains both Cs-137 and Co-60 isotopes. Cs-137 undergoes β- decay, while Co-60 also undergoes β- decay but with the additional emission of gamma rays at 1173 keV.
